Xi Jinping's state visit to Japan postponed due to coronavirus. China yesterday said President Xi Jinping's state visit to Japan would be postponed because of the coronavirus outbreak. 
 The trip, initially expected next month, would have been the first of its kind in nearly a decade and had been touted as a sign of warming ties between the world's second-and third-largest economies. 
 China and Japan are both currently fighting the novel coronavirus epidemic, said Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian at a press briefing in Beijing. 
 "Both sides agreed on the necessity of ensuring that Chairman Xi Jinping's state visit to Japan takes place at the most appropriate timing, environment and atmosphere, and achieves full success." 
 The two sides "will maintain close communication regarding the timing of the visit", he added. 
 This comes as China yesterday reported 139 new coronavirus infections, slightly up from 119 the previous day, taking the total number of infections to 80,409. There were 31 new deaths, all from outbreak epicentre Hubei province, taking the death toll to 3,012. 
 It appears that a strict lockdown of cities and other travel restrictions across the country are paying off, with official figures showing a steady drop in new cases in recent weeks, leading some provinces to lower their emergency response levels. But China is now concerned about imported infections, with the virus having spread to some 80 countries, infecting more than 15,000 and killing more than 200 overseas. 
 Meanwhile, Japan will suspend existing visas for visitors from China and South Korea and quarantine them for two weeks, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe told a Cabinet-level task force yesterday. 
 Agence France-Presse reported that the measure would start on Monday and last at least until the end of the month. 
 Mr Abe also reportedly asked that flights from China and South Korea use only two airports - Narita airport east of Tokyo and Kansai airport in Osaka. 
 Japan will also suspend the transport of passengers from China and South Korea by ship in and out of Japan, and cancel temporary and multiple-entry visas for visitors from the two countries. 
 Meanwhile, China is considering donating money to the World Health Organisation to help battle the coronavirus, its Vice-Minister of Foreign Affairs said. 
 Mr Ma Zhaoxu told a news briefing yesterday that China will make donations to South Korea, Iraq, Cambodia and Sri Lanka, on top of what it has already given to Pakistan, Japan and Iran. 
 Mr Ma said, thanks to diplomatic relations, China received donations of protective equipment and medical supplies when it was in the throes of the outbreak. 
 He specially mentioned Pakistan, which gave masks to China from its national inventory. 
 But other gifts were less conventional: Myanmar provided rice, Sri Lanka provided black tea, and during a state visit last week, Mongolian President Khaltmaagiin Battulga gave China 30,000 sheep.

Coronavirus testing counters in Northeast airports. In view of the Novel Coronavirus threat in China, the Airport Authority of India (AAI) with the help of the concerned state governments has set up screening and testing counters in most of the airports of northeast India, a top AAI official said on Monday.
Officials in Mizoram capital Aizawl said that two people, who had returned to the state from China early January, have been kept under house quarantine in view of the outbreak of the deadly Coronavirus in the neighbouring country.
An official of Mizoram Health Department said that though both the person did not show any sign of being infected with the virus and both of them tested negative for the deadly virus, they were put under house quarantine as a precautionary measure.
AAI Regional Executive Director (NER) Sanjeev Jindal said that the Lokopriya Gopinath Bordoloi international airport in Guwahati is the only airport in the northeast region from where the international flight operations took place with Singapore and Bhutan.
He told IANS that following the standard operating procedure (SOP) received from the central government, a special screening, testing and checking counter with the help of the Assam government has been functioning at the Guwahati airport since last week.
A special ambulance is also kept ready at the Guwahati airport and an isolated unit has also created in a Guwahati hospital for the suspected patient. Similar such screening and testing counters were set up in the other major airports including Agartala's Maharaja Bir Bikram airport, Lengpui airport in Mizoram and Imphal airport in Manipur.
Jindal said that the Coronavirus screening teams at the Guwahati airport has been equipped with various instruments including infrared thermometer to check body temperature and other symptoms.
"No case of the Coronavirus suspect has been detected in northeast India. No reason to be panicky. None should not be hide any kind of symptom. Airlines have been asked to to give announcement before landing so that the doubtful or suspected passengers could be able to screen and test them," the AAI Regional Executive Director said.

No, garlic does not protect against the coronavirus. Letters and parcels from China? Can be received without risk. Pneumonia vaccinations? Do not help against the new corona virus. Should You Eat Garlic? It is healthy, but there is no evidence that it protects against the pathogen. These questions and answers come from the World Health Organization (WHO) website. The WHO tries to fight myths under a rubric called myth busters. The United Nations authority wants to counter the rumors about the new corona virus. Because rumors, misinformation and conspiracy theories spread faster than the virus itself. At the end of 2019, a new virus broke out in China, 2019nCoV, closely related to the deadly Sars virus. Thousands of people have now been infected, hundreds have died, and several countries have long reported cases. Because the pathogen was still unknown last year and the consequences of the outbreak cannot yet be assessed, the need for knowledge is great: Google Trends recorded a rapidly increasing number of searches for the coronavirus in January. A demand that does not go unmet: In the past four weeks, more than 15 million tweets about the coronavirus have been posted on Twitter, and new news and assessments appear in the media every day. There are so many contributions that the WHO writes of an infodemy, an overabundance of information - correct, but also wrong. In general, a distinction must be made between unsecured information, out of context or false news, and conspiracy theories. For example, there is a story circulating online about a couple who allegedly left their two sick children at the airport. There is no evidence for this. The same applies to a video that spreads alleged facts about the virus in an alarmist tone. The allegations in it are partly exaggerated, partly unfounded, partly false, as the Correctiv portal has researched. But there are also conspiracy theories. It is said that the outbreak is based on a plot by Microsoft founder Bill Gates. That is also not true. Now this information may still be found harmless. However, the misinformation that is spreading around the new coronavirus is partly harmful, even life-threatening. For example, when they advertise alleged remedies or treatments. The Indian Ministry of Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy advises homeopathic treatment of coronavirus lung disease. The effect of homeopathy beyond the placebo effect has not been proven. And it is rumored on Facebook that drinking a chemical solution called MMS will cure a coronavirus infection. This is not only wrong, but even life-threatening if used. Facebook, usually not known for its intensive engagement with false content, has now announced that it will remove relevant posts from its platform. Twitter not only wants to delete misleading posts, but also only display credible information when searching for the coronavirus, according to a blog post. The media dynamics that can be observed at the moment are not new. It is similar to that of other news situations - be it a terrorist attack or a plane crash: First something bad happens, then information spreads on social media in a matter of minutes, and finally media reports. People read posts or articles, looking for more information, for certainty. But because there is still little reliable knowledge, there is room for rumors, misinformation and even conspiracy theories. The effect is reinforced by the fact that the level of knowledge about the center of the news situation - in this case the coronavirus disease - can constantly change and what seems certain today could be refuted tomorrow. Nicole Krämer works as a professor of social psychology at the University of Duisburg-Essen and researches fake news, among other things. She sees several reasons for the spread of false and unsecured information: "Much is still unclear about the coronavirus," she says, "that creates uncertainty." And because the outbreak threatens to become a pandemic and everyone in Germany could at some point run the risk of being infected, the need for information is particularly great. People sent information they see too quickly, says Krämer - often without reading the message carefully. Images with particularly frightening motifs, such as photos from overcrowded hospital corridors with patients lying on the floor, fueled this: "Some texts are certainly passed on because the power of images is so strong," says Krämer. We are all responsible for spreading false information. "It is less relevant who puts the wrong message into the world, but rather who spreads it. And these are mostly people, not bots," says Krämer. But of course, misinformation is not just spread unknowingly. There are also actors who specifically disseminate the information, says Krämer. This could be lay people who just want attention, but also state actors who want to create unrest. In addition, when it comes to health issues, a lot is trusted in the experience of others, said communication scientist Markus Schäfer from the University of Mainz to ZDF. Together with colleagues, he investigated how Internet users obtain information about health. According to this, almost every second respondent (46 percent) stated that they found out about health issues in personal conversations with family, friends and colleagues. 39 percent use the Internet for this, in the age group from 18 to 29 it was even 46 percent (specialist journal for online advice and computer-mediated communication: Schäfer et al., 2019). But health issues are often very complex. "This is why misinformation spreads so well in this area," says Schäfer. Medicine is not an exact science. In medical practice, scientific knowledge and experience flow together. Sometimes there is more room for rumors than for scientific questions. The effect of such false information is problematic not only in the short term, but also in the long term. In psychology, one speaks of the false information effect: If one reads false information immediately after an event, this can lead to the fact that one should remember it - even if one should actually know that it is not correct (e.g. Loftus, 2005). "This is normal in evolutionary psychology," says social psychologist Krämer. We first believed what we saw and didn't immediately doubt everything. The problem is that false information is received in the same way as facts. The wrong information can only be overwritten with difficulty. Therefore, even after people have read a correction, they can remember the wrong information. It becomes even more difficult when the misinformation you read fits into your own view of the world. Because we all tend to believe what we want to believe. In psychology this is called confirmation bias. In the case of the coronavirus, this is easy to observe: Anyone who wants to believe that the world is in the middle of a pandemic will find and share information that goes with it. Anyone who wants to believe that the pathogen is harmless will find the opposite information. It is currently unclear how deadly the virus really is - and whether the outbreak will take on global proportions. So how can you be sure that what you read is really correct? "Anyone who sees a text online shouldn't just share it, but read it through," says social psychologist Krämer. It also helps to pay attention to the sources. Is a contribution based on scientific knowledge? Can what is written there be checked? Is someone just quoting from other media? What is the original source? Is there even one? This may sound trite, but it can effectively help identify misinformation. The media are also responsible for correcting reports if they originally contained incorrect information, said Krämer. Experts are already looking for a global media strategy for future disease outbreaks. "We need effective media monitors to monitor how disease outbreaks are reported," wrote Ilona Kickbusch, professor of global health in Geneva, and Gabriel Leung, dean of medicine at Hong Kong University, in a contribution to the British Medical Journal. In the future, WHO should not only contact social media, but also work with well-known fact checkers. In this way you can also find out whether information is being withheld or critical journalists are being silenced. At the end of 2019, the Chinese authorities reported to the World Health Organization WHO an accumulation of pneumonia of unknown cause in the central Chinese city of Wuhan. Just a week later, Chinese researchers identified a novel virus as the cause of the disease. It belongs to the group of coronaviruses. A few days later, a group led by virologist Christian Drosten from the Berlin Charité published the first diagnostic test for the new virus, which researchers are provisionally calling 2019-nCoV. The test can be used to detect the virus in the laboratory. The Chinese authorities suspect the source of the pathogen to be a food market in Wuhan, where not only fish and seafood but also exotic animals such as snakes were sold. The market was closed and disinfected. Both Sars (severe acute respiratory syndrome) and Mers (Middle East respiratory syndrome) are caused by coronaviruses that originate in animals. During the Sars pandemic in 2002 and 2003, around 8,000 people were infected and more than 750 died. Between its discovery in 2012 and the end of 2019, around 2,500 people were infected with the Mers virus, and every third person died from it. In total, however, there are several hundred types of coronavirus. Many of them affect the respiratory tract and can cause colds, for example. Several thousand people have now become ill in China, some of them - most of them probably with previous illnesses - died of pneumonia as a result of the virus. The first cases of infection outside of China became known in Thailand, Japan and South Korea. These are travelers who had previously been to Wuhan. On January 21, US authorities reported the first infection in a tourist who was returning from Wuhan, and on January 24, the first cases in France became known. In the meantime, the first cases in Germany have also been confirmed. Typical signs of infection are fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. The virus can cause pneumonia, which can be fatal. Since it is a viral disease, antibiotics won't help. It is now clear that the virus can be transmitted from person to person. Chinese authorities have confirmed several such transmissions after a dozen or so cases among medical personnel became known. Doctors assume that the virus is mainly transmitted via droplet infection. As it announced on January 24, the World Health Organization currently expects that an infected person will infect an average of 1.4 to 2.5 other people. If these numbers prove to be true, the virus is less contagious than Sars and so is the flu. The WHO recommends following general hygiene rules: You should wash your hands often and avoid close contact with people with respiratory diseases and wild animals. It is not yet possible to say with certainty. The World Health Organization announced on January 28th that around a fifth of the reported cases would become seriously ill from the virus, so if in doubt they would have to be treated in intensive care. According to reports, the first fatalities were patients, some of whom had serious previous illnesses. People with previous illnesses are also particularly at risk from other infectious diseases - such as the flu. Coronaviruses are known to mutate, i.e. change their genetic makeup. That can make them more dangerous to people in the course of an outbreak - but also the exact opposite. The Robert Koch Institute (RKI) does not currently expect a mortality rate that is as high as that of the Sars outbreak. You can read more about the outbreak of the new coronavirus here.

UPDATE 1-Germany is at start of coronavirus epidemic -health minister. (Adds details, quotes)
BERLIN, Feb 26 (Reuters) - Germany is at the beginning of a coronavirus epidemic after new cases sprung up that can no longer be traced to the virus’s original source in China, Health Minister Jens Spahn said on Wednesday.
A total of five new cases of coronavirus in the west and south of Germany - taking the country’s total to around 20 - meant the disease appeared to be moving to a new phase, Spahn told a news conference, urging health authorities and employers to review their pandemic planning.
“The infection chains are partially no longer trackable, and that is a new thing,” Spahn said.
“Large numbers of people have had contact with the patients, and that is a big change to the 16 patients we had until now where the chain could be traced back to the origin in China.”
He warned against unnecessary panic, saying “not every cough is a case of coronavirus”. Spahn added that Germany was well equipped with isolation wards in hospitals if they should be needed in larger numbers.
“We are acting swiftly and adapting our reactions to the current situation, and unfortunately I have to say that the situation has changed in the past hours,” he said.
In Europe, Italy has become a front line in the global outbreak with 322 cases. Italians, or people who had recently visited the country, have tested positive in Algeria, Austria, Croatia, Romania, Spain and Switzerland.
A second person suffering from the coronavirus died in France as health officials tried to find out how the college teacher, who had not visited any country with a known outbreak, had caught the new disease.
The new coronavirus, believed to have originated from illegal wildlife sold in the Chinese city of Wuhan late last year, has infected some 80,000 people and killed more than 2,700 people, most of them in China. (Reporting by Thomas Escritt Editing by Gareth Jones/Mark Heinrich)

Markets nosedive: 3 factors that triggered Thursday’s Sensex, Nifty crash. Indian benchmark equity indices on Thursday collapsed once again as Sensex fell over 2,500 points while Nifty was down over 760 points or over seven per cent. The stock market shock comes a day after the World Health Organisation (WHO) declared the coronavirus outbreak as a pandemic.
As far as domestic stock markets are concerned, the freefall has led to a significant rise in the volatility index, which indicates that investors still remain worried about the prevailing economic disruptions caused by the coronavirus outbreak.
Here are key factors which led to the bloodbath on D-Street on Thursday:
Coronavirus now a pandemic
The coronavirus is now a pandemic, declared WHO on Thursday. The development was announced by WHO in view of the rapid rise in Covid-19 infections around the globe. Declaring it as a pandemic triggered a massive slump in stock markets across the world. Asian, European and US market indices took a pounding as investors remain spooked. The US has suspended travel from Europe while India has suspended all tourist visa till April 15.
In the morning trade, aviation and tourism stocks plummeted sharply after as a result of the fresh restrictions on travel.
It is worth mentioning that the WHO has declared the novel coronavirus as a pandemic and added that Italy and Iran were the hotspot countries. It said other countries could join them soon.
The WHO declared the new coronavirus as a pandemic for the first time on Wednesday, adding that Italy and Iran were now on the frontline of the disease and other countries would soon join them. The global toll death toll has crossed 4,500 while India has recorded at least 73 positive cases.
Oil slides further
Another reason why domestic stock markets fell was a further slide in global crude oil prices. Oil prices have continued to slide since the major crash on March 6 following a meeting of the OPEC countries and Russia. A price war was triggered as Saudi slashed oil prices, resulting in the collapse of global crude oil prices.
While prices had recovered slightly on March 11, the lower prices keep hurting sentiments of major oil companies in the country. Power and energy companies are also taking a pounding in the domestic stock market due to reduced prices. Though the general notion is that India benefits from any cut in global crude prices, the recent deep cut may not be ideal for the country.
Sharp fall in oil prices also has a greater impact on the equity market, as witnessed in the past few days. It could even disrupt the flow for foreign capital into the India market if crude prices keep falling.
Global market rout
Not just India but markets around the globe have witnessed carnage over the past few days due to the coronavirus outbreak. From Dow Jones in the US to other major markets in the world, each one has registered serious falls due to rising doubts over the total financial impact of the virus outbreak.
Stock markets around the world crumbled after Trump's move, with U.S. stock index futures diving 4.7% and MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan tumbling 4.1% to its lowest level since early 2019.
As the virus keeps spreading across the globe rapidly, analysts expect the carnage to continue until there is a global decline in new positive cases.
Investors will also be monitoring the situation in China, which conveyed that the number of cases in the epicentre Hubei province and Wuhan reduced significantly.

The Wuhan coronavirus | Spain estimates that the epidemic may "soon subside". The number of those affected by the Wuhan coronavirus in China reaches 9,720 and already exceeds the total of cases in the 2003 SARS epidemic worldwide, 8,096. The fatalities reached 213 people this Friday, according to official data. The 2019-nCoV coronavirus can cause pneumonia with symptoms such as high fever, dry cough, headache, and shortness of breath. Its average incubation period is three to seven days, with a maximum of 14. Chinese scientists have confirmed that, unlike SARS, contagion is possible during incubation. The WHO has declared an international emergency over the outbreak. Suspected cases now rise to 15,238, according to the National Health Commission, while 171 patients have managed to recover. 102,427 people who have been in contact with infected people are kept under observation. Most of the deceased, 90%, come from the province of Hubei, where the city of Wuhan and the focus of the epidemic is located. In the last 24 hours, in which 43 deaths have been registered, all but one corresponded to this province. Spain is already applying "almost everything that the WHO says", an organization that this Thursday declared an international emergency due to the expansion of the coronavirus. The director of the Center for the Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies of the Ministry of Health, Fernando Simón, explained to the press on Friday that these measures are not substantially different from what the WHO recommended a week ago, and that they do not include or restrictions on travel or trade, informs Pablo Linde. "We do not expect that in Spain there will be more than an imported case. We do not believe that transmissions will take place here, but we are preparing for that scenario," said Simón. The director of the Center for the Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies has been surprised by the declaration of the state of emergency in Italy. "It is not the consensus of the EU and in Spain at the moment it is not being considered," he assured. With the preliminary data, "the indications are that the disease is not excessively communicable. It is only transmitted in a community way in one area and it seems that the epidemic has the possibility of beginning to remit soon," he said. The transmission zone is only Hubei, the province of China where Wuhan is located. "There are Chinese provinces with fewer cases than other countries. It would be inconsistent to recommend not traveling to the entire country," he said. Simón explained that three doctors and a nurse will accompany the Spanish evacuees from Wuhan on their flight, which took off this morning from the Chinese city. Citizens of Nordic countries traveling on board will be taken to their countries of origin as soon as they land at Torrejón de Ardoz airport, in Spain. The Italian Council of Ministers has approved this Friday a decree declaring a state of emergency for the coronavirus, following the decision of the World Health Organization to decree the global emergency. "It is simply a matter of taking note of the WHO's decision," Italian government sources have said. The Government has allocated an initial five million euros to deal with the spread of the virus. The Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has explained that they are precautionary measures, and that in light of the international emergency declaration, the regulatory instruments for these cases have been activated. Italy already declared a state of health emergency when the SARS epidemic was registered in 2002. This mechanism, used for example after earthquakes or floods such as those in Venice, allows activating funds and mobilizing organizations, such as civil protection, in order to to prepare structures for welcoming people. Italian Prime Minister Guiseppe Conte confirmed on Thursday two cases of coronavirus, affecting two Chinese tourists who arrived in the country in January. As a precautionary measure, Italian authorities have decided to cancel air connections with China to prevent the spread of the outbreak. Also this Thursday, 6,000 passengers were blocked aboard a cruise ship in the Roman port of Civitavecchia in which there was a couple who had symptoms compatible with the coronavirus. Finally, after confirming the negative results of the tests, the passenger can disembark. "We can confirm that two patients in England, members of the same family, have tested positive," announced the head of the English medical services, Chris Whitty, in a statement released by the Ministry of Health, in which they have not given more details about those affected to preserve their privacy. Outside of China, the epidemic has spread to a score of countries, accumulating around 130 cases. The two affected in England "are receiving specialized care from the health services" and "infection control procedures are being used to prevent the virus from spreading," according to Whitty. British medical experts had already warned that it was "highly probable" that cases of coronavirus would be registered in the United Kingdom. "The National Health Service is extremely well prepared and used to managing infections and we are already working quickly to identify anyone who has come into contact with patients to prevent further spread," added Whitty. Thailand, the country with the most affected after China, with 19 cases, has confirmed the first direct contagion between humans produced within the country. India has also confirmed its first positive, reports Ángel Martínez. This is an Indian student from Wuhan, who had been in an isolation ward for a week in the Thrissur district, in the southern state of Kerala. Russia also announced the first two confirmed cases on Friday. While the plane chartered by the British Government that transports its citizens and the twenty evacuated Spaniards has already landed at the British air base of Brize Norton, other countries continue the repatriation of their nationals. The military plane with the first 180 French returnees from Wuhan landed this Friday at noon at the Istres air base, in southern France, Silvia Ayuso reports. Although they had tested negative for the coronavirus 2019-nCoV before taking off from the Chinese city, one of the passengers presented symptoms during the flight and was immediately taken to the Marseilles hospital in Timone, the Minister of Health, Agnès Buzyn, announced that went to receive the returnees. The others were transferred to a holiday center in Carry-le-Rouet, a town on the Mediterranean coast 30 kilometers from Marseille, where they will have to spend the next 14 days in quarantine. The enclosure meets the requirements that the authorities had imposed when looking for a place to welcome returnees: “A criterion above all sanitary with isolated rooms, which is also close to a hospital and, furthermore, which is pleasant and warm. The Carry-le-Rouet holiday center met all of those criteria, ”Buzyn explained. Although the returnees, who must undergo tests twice a day to verify that they do not have symptoms, will be able to move freely around the compound, they will not be able to leave it - several gendarmes stationed abroad will ensure that no one leaves or enters without permission - and they must carry masks when in common areas. In addition, the minister said, although they may receive packages, family visits will not be allowed. More than fifty health professionals will take turns during the next two weeks to accompany and supervise the repatriated citizens, to whom a new contingent could join in the next few days, since as announced by the European Commission, it is expected that a new plane is chartered to transport other French citizens who wish to leave Wuhan, as well as other foreigners who can also do so, in principle mainly Europeans. In Paris, the Pasteur Institute announced this Friday that it has managed to isolate the strains of the coronavirus detected in France and has set up a working group to search for possible solutions, including a vaccine that could be available in 20 months. As explained by its scientific director, Christophe d'Enfert, the idea is to work on a modification of the measles vaccine. "We have developed a platform that in eight months will allow us to obtain an attenuated virus that we can test in animals," he explained. "If all goes well," he stressed, the clinical phase could be entered at the end of August, he added. Taking as a model the work done on Ebola, he said, it should last a year and, again "if everything goes well", a vaccine could be available in a period of time of 20 months. Meanwhile, a flight organized by the South Korean government has landed this Friday in Seoul with 368 people on board, the first of a series of four to rescue people of this nationality. One of those on the list was unable to board due to fever, and 18 of the passengers have been sent to hospital upon arrival. The rest of the returnees will be quarantined in isolation centers in the cities of Asan and Jincheon, about 80 kilometers south of Seoul, a decision that has sparked protests among its residents. The United States, which has issued a "do not travel" alert to China due to the coronavirus, has indicated that it will send a second plane on February 3 after which this Wednesday it repatriated more than 200 of its citizens. Japan also asks its citizens from this Friday not to travel to China if it is not strictly necessary. This country on Thursday repatriated a third batch of nationals on a charter flight carrying 149 passengers. Eight of them were taken to a medical center by ambulance, as reported by the Japanese television station NHK. The rest will be tested to determine if they are carriers of the virus and, while awaiting the results, will be housed in facilities offered by the government in Tokyo. Colombia, Costa Rica and El Salvador are also considering a joint evacuation of their nationals, who would leave Wuhan by land and would complete the quarantine in another Chinese city. If they do not show symptoms, these citizens will be able to travel to any other locality in the People's Republic or return to their nations of origin. As reported by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Bogotá, 14 of their compatriots have expressed their desire to get out of the focus of the epidemic. Following the WHO declaration of international emergency, El Salvador has banned the entry of travelers from China to its borders. "We hope it is a temporary measure," said the president of the Central American country, Nayib Bukele, at a press conference. The Philippines adopted a similar veto on Friday for those from Hubei province. Singapore has banned all Chinese or non-Chinese visitors who have recently traveled to China. The measure, one of the most restrictive so far to try to contain the spread of the virus, will be effective from this Saturday, and will also apply to passengers in transit. As an exception, there are residents and holders of long-term permits, such as work or student visas. Mongolia, which shares a border of almost 5,000 kilometers with China, has announced the closure of its access to foreign citizens from its neighboring country at least until February 2. It has also asked for the return of its nationals who are currently in China, and who will have until the 6th to return. Ulan Bator is also trying to get thirty of its citizens trapped in Wuhan out. Hours after the emergency committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) decided on Thursday night in Geneva to declare an international emergency due to the outbreak of the Wuhan coronavirus, the Chinese government has assured that it is capable of “stopping and defeat ”the epidemic. In a statement, the National Health Commission has assured that "China is confident and capable of effectively containing the new epidemic and ultimately defeating it." The statement emphasizes that Beijing "attaches great importance to the prevention and control of pneumonia caused by the new coronavirus and has taken the strictest measures to curb the epidemic." The Chinese government has sent two planes to Malaysia and Thailand to repatriate to about 200 citizens residing in Wuhan, and who were abroad when the closure of the city was announced in the middle of the holiday season for the Chinese New Year, as announced on Friday by the Chinese civil aviation authority. These are two Boeing 737s from the Chinese company Xiamen Airlines. The Chinese Embassy in Japan has also asked the Shanghai-based Spring Airlines to provide charter flights for the Wuhan people who have been held in Japan. The first of those flights will depart from Tokyo airport this Saturday. The decision has been made, according to the spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Hua Chunying, given the "practical difficulties" that these residents, "especially those from Wuhan", have encountered abroad. According to data from the local government of Hubei, at the time of the blockade of Wuhan and fifteen other cities with a total population of 46 million people, some 40,000 residents of the province were abroad. Among them, the largest contingent, some 10,000 people, was concentrated in Thailand, the number one destination for Chinese tourists. The head of the infectious diseases department of the prestigious Sino-Japanese Friendship Hospital in Beijing, Zhan Qinghhuan, addressed a press conference this Friday to those recovering from the coronavirus infection. Although they will develop antibodies that will initially protect them from a new infection, these "may not remain long" in the immune system, so "there is a risk that those who have been cured may be re-infected. They must protect themselves adequately," he insisted. , according to the newspaper South China Morning Post. In the last 24 hours, 47 patients across China who have overcome the infection have been discharged. Faced with growing criticism of the way in which the local authorities in Wuhan and Hubei managed the beginning of the crisis, the first layoffs have already begun to take place. Tang Zhihong, head of the Health Department in the city of Huanggang, neighboring Wuhan and the second in the country by number of cases of infection, was the first official to be relieved of her position. Huanggang has reported close to 500 confirmed cases and 12 deaths in his municipality, but when asked by a team of central government inspectors on television cameras about the situation at one of the hospitals under his charge, Tang was unable to respond. . "I only know how many beds she has, but not how many people she is treating," she acknowledged. Tang's response had generated a wave of negative comments on Chinese social media. Her admission came after Wuhan Mayor Zhou Xianwang acknowledged earlier in the week that the municipal government did not release the information available to it in the first weeks of the crisis as quickly as possible. Zhou, however, specified that, if he had withheld data, it was because he did not receive authorization from higher levels of government to release it.

China identifies 62 people infected with unknown virus. Scientists warn that there are already 1723. Chinese authorities have announced that there are 17 more people infected in the center of the country with a new form of viral pneumonia, which has caused two deaths and has put other countries on alert. In total, 62 cases of the new coronavirus were registered by the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission, with 19 being discharged from hospital, while two men in their 60s - one with serious pre-existing conditions - died from the disease. At least half a dozen countries in Asia have adopted exceptional measures. The number of people infected with the virus probably exceeds a thousand cases and is much higher than that advanced by local authorities, according to British investigators. In an article published on Friday by scientists at a research center at the Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine in London, it is pointed out that the number of people infected in the Chinese city will be much higher. Researchers at the Center for the Global Analysis of Infectious Diseases, which advises institutions such as the World Health Organization (WHO), estimate that "a total of 1,723 cases" in Wuhan had had symptoms of the disease as of 12 January. The warning of the spread of the virus was given this week by the WHO, after the first cases detected outside China were known, in Thailand and Japan, with the three patients having visited Wuhan recently. Cases of viral pneumonia fueled fears about a potential epidemic after research identified the disease as a new type of coronavirus, a species of virus that causes respiratory infections in humans and animals and is transmitted through coughing, sneezing or contact. physicist. In response to this information, the United States announced on Friday that it will monitor passengers on flights from Wuhan to airports in Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York. This is a period of increased movement of citizens to and from China because of the Chinese New Year celebrations on the 25th.

Delta will not charge a replacement ticket to China until February 29th. NEW YORK, January 28. / TASS /. The American airline Delta Air Lines has extended from January 31 to February 29 the benefit that allows passengers to avoid additional costs for a one-time flight plan change, including a ticket change. This is due to an outbreak of pneumonia caused by the new 2019-nCoV coronavirus, according to a message posted on the airline's website. The notice applies to Beijing and Shanghai. “The one-time travel plan change fee exemption gives our customers additional leeway,” Delta explained. The previous term of this benefit was from January 24 to January 31. It has now been extended until February 29th. The airline has warned its passengers that, in addition to checks in China, they will be subject to checks upon arrival at airports in New York, San Francisco, Atlanta, Chicago and Los Angeles. This is done by employees of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). CDC has confirmed five cases of new pneumonia in the country. All five cases visited the Chinese city of Wuhan, where an outbreak of pneumonia caused by the new coronavirus was recorded. The cases have occurred in four states: Arizona, Washington, Illinois and California. On Monday, the US State Department called on Americans to reconsider travel plans to China due to the coronavirus. The foreign ministry also recommended refraining from travel to the Chinese province of Hubei, whose administrative center is the city of Wuhan.

Several airlines suspend or reduce flights to China. Coronavirus: No new confirmed cases in Singapore for a second day. SINGAPORE - There were no new cases of the coronavirus infection here for a second day, according to an update by the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Monday evening (Feb 3). 
 This means the total number of confirmed cases in Singapore remains at 18, including two Singaporeans. There were no new cases reported on Sunday. 
 The MOH reiterated that there is currently no evidence of community spread of the virus in Singapore. The virus, known as 2019-nCoV, first emerged in the Chinese city of Wuhan in December last year. 
 None of the 18 previously announced cases is critically ill. All of them remain in stable condition, and most are improving, the ministry added. 
 As of noon on Monday, 262 of the suspected cases have tested negative for the virus. Test results for the remaining 32 cases are pending. Contact tracing for the confirmed cases is being carried out. 
 The MOH said that once a confirmed case has been identified, it will closely monitor all close contacts. As a precautionary measure, they will be quarantined for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient. 
 In addition, all other identified contacts who have a low risk of being infected will be under active surveillance, and will be contacted daily to monitor the status of their health. 
 The ministry has identified 256 close contacts as of noon on Monday, with 187 still in Singapore, of which 186 have been contacted and are being quarantined or isolated.  
 Efforts are being made to contact the  remaining close contact. 
 The authorities earlier said that two Singaporean women evacuated from Wuhan had been infected with the coronavirus. 
 The women, both aged 47, were asymptomatic when they boarded the specially arranged Scoot flight TR121 that carried 92 Singaporeans from the Chinese city, which is on lockdown. They are currently admitted at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID), along with the majority of the other confirmed infected cases. 
 The coronavirus has so far proven to be more infectious than Sars. 
 As of Monday, the outbreak had sickened more than 17,000 and killed more than 360, with the Philippines reporting the first death caused by the virus outside of China. The deceased was a 44-year-old Wuhan resident who travelled from China to the Philippines. 
 Most of the deaths occurred in central Hubei province, the epicentre of the outbreak. 
 In the wake of the outbreak, a growing number of countries, including Italy, the United States, Australia, Singapore, Japan and Russia, have put in place travel restrictions. Germany, France and the US have evacuated citizens from China. 
 Several major airlines have also halted flights to and from China, deepening concerns of a widespread economic slowdown. 
 In Singapore, measures to combat the outbreak include mask distribution at residents' committee centres and community centres islandwide, which began last Saturday. 
 The Government announced last Thursday that all 1.3 million households in Singapore would be given a pack of four masks each amid reports of shops running out of stocks. 
 Residents collecting their masks at Toa Payoh Central Zone 4 RC on Feb 1, 2020. ST PHOTO: CHONG JUN LIANG 
 The MOH on Monday continued to advise Singaporeans to defer all travel to Hubei province and all non-essential travel to mainland China. 
 All travellers should monitor their health closely for two weeks after returning to Singapore and seek medical attention promptly if they feel unwell. 
 Travellers should inform their doctors where they have travelled. If they have a fever or respiratory symptoms – such as a cough or shortness of breath – they should wear a mask and call the clinic ahead of the visit. 
 Members of the public should take precautions such as avoiding contact with live animals, including poultry and birds, and avoid eating raw and undercooked meat. 
 They should also avoid close contact with people who are unwell or showing symptoms of illness. 
 The public can observe good personal hygiene too, with frequent hand washing using soap, such as before handling food or eating, after going to toilet, or when hands are dirtied after coughing or sneezing. 
 People should a wear a mask if they have respiratory symptoms such as a cough or shortness of breath. 
 When sneezing or coughing, they should cover their mouths with a  tissue paper and throw it in the rubbish bin immediately.

wuhan doctors battle covid-19 outbreak in diapers as masks rub their faces raw. HONG KONG — Medical personnel in Wuhan, outfitted in protective suits as they battle the coronavirus outbreak, wear diapers as they work through gruelling shifts, often until skin irritation from their masks leaves bloody marks on their faces, a news briefing was told on Wednesday (Feb 12). 
 “When doctors and nurses are in the ward,” dressed in protective clothing that seals them off from the environment, “they cannot eat, drink or go to the bathroom”, Dr Han Ding, deputy director of the Peking Union Medical College Hospital in Beijing, told reporters in Wuhan, the epicentre of the outbreak. 
 “Just in case they must urinate, they [wear a] diaper, and wash up after they’re done with their shift,” he said. 
 Dr Han is one of hundreds of doctors brought in from beyond Wuhan to support the round-the-clock fight against the coronavirus. So far, the disease has killed more than 1,300 people worldwide, with all but two of the deaths in mainland China. Also known as novel coronavirus, or Covid-19, the illness had infected more than 60,000 globally as of Thursday. 
 Leaders of medical teams described the difficult working conditions during the daily briefing held by the government of Hubei, the central China province in which Wuhan is located. 
 “Wearing the protective suits is extremely uncomfortable,” said Dr Ma Xin, deputy dean of Huashan Hospital in Shanghai. “Sometimes I want to itch, but we absolutely cannot do that, so we just have to bear it. 
 “Our doctors and nurses all have signs of irritation and even bloody marks on the bridges of their noses. These are the conditions of their work.” 
 Dr Han said medical staff were working around the clock to care for those in the most critical condition. Nurses were putting in 4-6 hour shifts in intensive care units, while doctors were working from 6-8 hours, though shifts could go even longer, he said. 
 “Doctors and nurses are wearing their equipment so long you can see the marks on their faces,” said Dr Zhou Jun, party secretary of the China-Japan Friendship Hospital in Beijing. 
 Dr Zhou, who serves at Tongji hospital in Wuhan, said medical staff were doing all they could to save lives, given limited supplies. 
 Advanced equipment brought in from around the nation is playing a critical role in the struggle with the virus, Dr Ma said. 
 “In the absence of specific medicines [for the virus], ventilators and ECMO are of great importance in the treatment,” he said. He was referring to ECMO machines, which circulate a patient’s blood through an artificial lung, giving the lungs of those in the most critical condition an opportunity to rest and recover. 
 Respirators, artificial lung machines and other equipment also play a vital role in keeping the death rate from climbing higher. 
 Dr Zhou said his team brought with them 15 million yuan (S$2.98 million) of cutting-edge equipment from Beijing, including not only ECMO machines but ventilators, monitors, bronchoscopes and other devices. 
 “Some of this equipment is very expensive, but plays a critical role in curing patients,” Dr Zhou said. “The most important thing is to reduce the death rate, and increase the rate of those cured.” 
 The World Health Organization, seeking to distinguish the virus from the disease it causes, said on Tuesday that it had named the virus SARS-CoV-2, and the disease Covid-19. SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST

Identified the first infected in the United States by the Wuhan coronavirus. The new Wuhan virus, which has already left six dead in China and hundreds affected, has crossed the Pacific. A man in his 30s who traveled to that Chinese region was diagnosed with the virus last week in Seattle, Washington State, as confirmed by the United States Center for Disease Control (CDC) on Tuesday, while the entire country was glued to television to follow the impeachment against Donald Trump in the Senate. The Wuhan virus is a new coronavirus called 2019-nCov that is transmitted between humans and causes respiratory diseases. It was first detected less than a month ago. From this city, located in the central area of ​​the Chinese territory and where 11 million people live - more than London or New York -, the pathogen began to spread to neighboring provinces. Last Friday, for example, there were no positives out there, but now there are 38 cases spread over 15 other large Chinese cities and it has jumped to four countries in Southeast Asia. The Seattle patient, whose identity is unknown at the moment, is admitted to the Everett Regional Medical Center, the capital of Snohomish County (Washington). He is stable, responds to treatment, and is not considered a risk. The CDC has also explained that the patient had no symptoms when he landed on January 15 in the US He went to the doctor last Sunday and was hospitalized for pneumonia. The patient did not visit any of the Wuhan markets, where numerous cases of those affected by the virus were confirmed, but he did visit the region, Nancy Messonnier, director of the CDC's department of respiratory diseases, told reporters. The authorities are looking for all the people who have been in contact with the patient these days, Messonnier explained. They do not expect there to be more cases. Since last Friday, the 17th, the CDC had imposed special controls to monitor the possible entry of the virus into the country at the busiest airports on the West Coast, San Francisco and Los Angeles, and New York. They are the three airports with the most passengers from the Wuhan region. The CDC has posted about 100 workers to these airports and has installed quarantine rooms. The health authorities had been alert for two weeks. On January 11, they had published a Level 1 health warning for passengers who had been in Wuhan. A group of experts from the Center for Infectious Diseases Epidemiology at the University of Hong Kong suggests that the reality is even more worrying than the data offered by China. According to a report from him prepared in collaboration with the World Health Organization (WHO) and presented this Tuesday, the total number of infected may already touch 1,500: 1,343 in Wuhan and 115 in the rest of the country. In addition to China and the US, there have been cases of people with this virus detected in South Korea, Thailand, Japan and Taiwan, where a 55-year-old woman was also recognized this Tuesday with the disease. As in previous cases, she traveled to Wuhan in recent weeks. The island's Minister of Health, Chen Shih-chung, has assured that none of the relatives of the patient have any symptoms, similar to those of ordinary pneumonia, and that 46 other people who were in contact with her during the journey from aircraft have been placed under observation. In addition, the Philippines and Australia have also announced that they have taken action against the first suspected cases in their territory. The WHO paid a visit to Wuhan on Monday with a group of Chinese health experts, led by Dr. Zhong Nanshan, director of the State Laboratory of Infectious Diseases in Guangzhou and a national eminence in the matter. According to this conglomerate of experts, 15 medical employees in the city have contracted the virus, confirming human-to-human transmission - an extreme ruled out until last weekend. The escalation of this new coronavirus, discovered two weeks ago, is reminiscent of the SARS epidemic, with which it bears genetic similarities. The 2002 epidemic, also originating in China, killed 700 people worldwide. The WHO will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow Wednesday to decide whether to declare "an international public health emergency" due to the outbreak. The Chinese State Council, for its part, has also scheduled a press conference in which it will detail the evolution of the virus in the last hours.

Xi Jinping learned of the seriousness of the coronavirus two weeks before public speaking on the matter. Chinese state media on Saturday released a speech by President Xi Jinping that indicated that the Chinese leader was aware of the potential seriousness of the new coronavirus outbreak weeks before the population was alerted to the issue. At the start of the outbreak, Xi Jinping adopted a stance that many considered to be inactive, fueling a wave of criticism of the Chinese government's response to the crisis, which forced him this week to come to the forefront of combating the health crisis, launch a purge of Chinese Communist Party (CCP) leaders in Hubei Province, where the new virus emerged, and initiate reform in the way China handles health emergencies. In an unprecedented way, Chinese citizens, forced into a quarantine of gigantic proportions — tens of millions of people are confined to their homes, or subjected to control measures that severely limit their movement or contact with other people — demand more transparency in the State, more information about what's going on. Xi Jinping, as a source of authority in a highly centralized state, is forced to open some windows, letting a system used to secrecy air out, while tightening control elsewhere. It is through this prism that one should read this Sunday's release of the speech given on February 3 by Xi Jinping in which he reports having given orders, on January 7, during a meeting of the Standing Committee of the Politburo, the most powerful body in the Chinese policy to implement measures to prevent infections by the new coronavirus. The speech is published in Qiushi magazine — described by the People's Daily, the official newspaper of the CPC, as "a reference publication of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China". In this speech, accompanied by photos of Xi and other leaders in blue paper masks, the Chinese President says he authorized the unprecedented quarantine in Wuhan starting January 23 — a city of 11 million people, which is a major node of rail, river and air transport, with a technological and automotive production center for international brands, and also an important area of ​​agricultural production. Although Xi has reported his actions since the beginning of January, it was not until January 20th that Xi publicly spoke of the new disease and Chinese authorities acknowledged the existence of the epidemic in the city of Wuhan, which by then had already spread to other Chinese cities and other countries. It was on that day that authorities in Beijing confirmed that Covid-19 is spread between humans, at which point alarmism began to take on a new tone. Xi Jinping's advisers are believed to have believed that the release of this speech will show that the Chinese president was aware of the crisis from the beginning — they hope to defuse criticism for not appearing publicly to lead the actions against the emergency, which has already killed 1665 people. a total of 68,500 infections. "The overall tone of the speech seems defensive," Minxin Pei, professor of government at Claremont McKenna College in California, told the New York Times. "He wants to change the narrative, which so far has been very unfavorable to Chinese leaderships." "I followed, at all times, the spread of the epidemic and the progress in the efforts to contain it, constantly issuing oral orders and instructions", guaranteed Xi Jinping, in the speech quoted by the New York Times. Subscribe to newsletters for free and receive the best of current affairs and the most in-depth works from Público. The Chinese executive is now facing widespread criticism and public discontent, which escalated earlier this month after the death of Li Wenliang, the 34-year-old Chinese doctor, who issued warnings about the new virus and who was detained for “ spread rumors” and forced to sign a document to recant — and who died after contracting Covid-19. A few hours after the speech was released, China announced a drop in new Covid-19 cases for the third day in a row. New cases were reported this Sunday in mainland China, which excludes Macau and Hong Kong, bringing the total number to 68,500. The death rate remained stable, with 142 new deaths, reported the National Health Commission. The death toll in mainland China from the new coronavirus stood at 1665. There is still one death to be recorded in the Chinese Special Administrative Region of Hong Kong, one in the Philippines, one in Japan and one in France (recorded this Saturday), bringing the total death toll worldwide to 1,669.

China reports 39 new confirmed cases of coronavirus, all imported. BEIJING (REUTERS) - Mainland China saw a drop in its daily tally of new coronavirus cases, reversing four straight days of gains, as the country’s capital Beijing ramped up measures to contain the number of infections arriving from abroad. 
 China had 39 new confirmed cases on Sunday (March 22), the country’s National Health Commission said, down from 46 a day earlier. All of them involved travellers arriving from abroad. 
 The city of Beijing expanded measures to contain imported infections, diverting all international flights arriving from Monday to other airports where passengers will undergo virus screening. 
 Beijing reported 10 new imported cases, the National Health Commission said on Monday, down from 13 a day earlier. 
 Infections from abroad in the city hit an all-time high of 21 on March 18. 
 Shanghai and Guangzhou have also said all arriving international passengers will undergo tests to screen for the coronavirus, expanding a programme that previously only applied to those coming from heavily-affected countries. 
 Shanghai reported 10 new cases on Sunday, down from a record 14 a day earlier. With the coronavirus spread subsiding, the Shanghai government on Monday downgraded the city’s emergency alert level from level 1 to level 2.  
 Guangdong province saw seven new imported infections, Fujian had four and Jiangsu had two. Hebei, Zhejiang, Jiangxi, Shandong and Sichuan each saw just one case, bringing the total imported cases in China to 314 so far. 
 Mainland China saw no new locally transmitted infections. 
 As of Sunday, the total accumulated number of confirmed cases in mainland China stood at 81,093. 
 The death toll from the outbreak in mainland China reached 3,270, up by nine from the previous day.

ford hoards cash, withdraws profit forecast amid coronavirus outbreak. DETROIT - Ford Motor Co <F.N> on Thursday moved to hoard cash on its balance sheet, drawing down $15.4 billion from two credit lines and suspending its dividend, in a move to bolster reserves to ride out damage to its business from the coronavirus pandemic.  
 The No. 2 U.S. automaker, whose shares closed off slightly after sinking as much as 8.9% earlier in the day, also abandoned its 2020 financial forecast and said the cash would be used to deal with a squeeze on capital caused by shutdowns in production due to the fast-spreading virus.  
 The move will give Ford more than $37 billion in cash, almost matching the revenue it reported in the fourth quarter. That dwarfs the company's market capitalization of about $18 billion.  
 Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas said in a research note that corporate liquidity during the outbreak was "top of mind" and that U.S. automakers had strong balance sheets.  
 The coronavirus outbreak, which started in China last year, has caused about 219,000 infections and more than 8,900 deaths globally.  
 Comparing the current economic situation to the 2008-2009 financial crisis, Chief Executive Jim Hackett said Ford was putting in place safeguards to protect its business.  
 "We're at war with the virus and Ford is going to win," Hackett told employees on a video conference.  
 Ford has come under fire from some analysts on Wall Street for moving too slowly to cut costs and restructure its business.  
 At the end of last year, it had booked only $3.7 billion of the projected $11 billion in charges it previously said it would take in its global restructuring.  
 Since then, the outbreak has spread globally, leading Ford, General Motors Co <GM.N> and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV <FCHA.MI>, <FCAU.N> on Wednesday to announce the shutdown of their North American plants to prevent the spread of the disease among their factory workers.  
 All three Detroit automakers have seen U.S. employees test positive for COVID-19, the contagious respiratory illness caused by the virus.  
 Electric carmaker Tesla Inc <TSLA.O> on Thursday suspended production at its California car plant, starting March 24, to help stem the spread of the coronavirus, and added that its cash position was strong enough to navigate this period of uncertainty.  
  
 OUTLOOK REVISIONS  
 The outbreak has already hit other automakers and more are expected to slash their 2020 forecasts.  
 Evercore ISI analysts said in a research note that such actions "will be an ongoing theme in addition to the removal of (stock) buybacks."  
 On Wednesday, German luxury automaker BMW AG <BMWG.DE> cut its 2020 profit outlook, saying it would be "significantly lower" than last year. Two days before that, Chinese automaker Great Wall Motor Co Ltd <601633.SS> also cut its 2020 sales and profit targets.  
 GM and FCA did not change their profit forecasts on Thursday.  
 "We are dedicated to managing our cost structure against this dynamic environment," GM said in a statement. "We continue to monitor the situation closely and will make any necessary decisions to stay resilient."  
 GM had $34.6 billion in liquidity at the end of 2019, including $17.3 billion in cash.  
 "We are evaluating the impact of all steps being taken inside the company related to the coronavirus emergency on our current financial guidance," FCA said in a statement, adding it would provide an update when it has "sufficient visibility on market conditions."  
 FCA had 23.1 billion euros ($24.94 billion) in liquidity at the end of 2019.  
 Shares of Uber Technologies Inc <UBER.N> closed up more than 38% on Thursday after Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi said the ride-hailing company had plenty of cash on hand.  
 "In any crisis, liquidity is key," he said on an investor call.  
 Ford said on Thursday it notified lenders it would borrow the unused amounts of the two credit lines, totaling $15.4 billion. The Dearborn, Michigan-based company had $22 billion in cash at the end of last year.  
 The dividend suspension will save Ford money at an annual rate of $2.4 billion.  
 The company said it was prioritizing financial flexibility and investments in future technologies such as self-driving cars and a series of important 2020 vehicle launches including a redesigned version of its top-selling F-150 full-size pickup truck.  
 Ford also withdrew its 2020 profit outlook. In February, before the coronavirus hit the United States, it offered a weaker-than-expected forecast for earnings in the range of 94 cents to $1.20 a share.  
 Ford said it would update its outlook when it reports first-quarter results on April 28.  
 Also on Thursday, Ford said it would offer new-car buyers up to six months of payment relief. Some U.S. dealers have begun to see sales drop off because of the virus, which has already drastically hurt demand in other countries. REUTERS

Wuhan records first day without new coronavirus cases. According to the daily briefing issued by China’s National Health Commission, “on 18 March, Hubei reported no new infections, while 795 patients were released from hospital after being cured.”
In total, China reported 34 new confirmed infections on 18 March and eight deaths. Although the deceased were all in Hubei, the province did not report one single “suspected infection” for the first time since the outbreak of the epidemic.
The overall toll for China now stands at 80,928 cases, of which 70,420 have been cured and “discharged from hospital,” and a total of 3,245 deaths.
Over the weekend, the number of coronavirus cases and deaths outside China surpassed the domestic statistics.
Beijing tells others how to tackle the crisis
As a result, China now feels confident about advising other countries on how to tackle the crisis.
“China decided to lock-down Wuhan, the capital of Hubei province and the epicentre of the epidemic in China,” says the CCP-controlled Global Times.
The aim was “to prevent the transmission of the virus within the city and to other places, demonstrating China's responsibility to ensure the safety and health of the people of Wuhan, Hubei, the whole of China, and even the world.
“Indeed,” continues the paper, “it was a tough choice for China to make on the eve of the country's most important festival," a reference to the Spring Festival which is normally the occasion for family reunions.
While not directly criticising less stringent measures taken in some western countries, the Global Times quotes praise by World Health Organization Director General, Tedros Adhamon Ghebreyesus, for the Chinese approach that resulted in “winning time for the rest of the world”.
The highest form of human rights
The unnamed author, an “expert on human rights studies” according to the attribution under the Global Times article, uses the way China has dealt with the coronavirus outbreak as proof that Beijing cares more about human rights than the West.
Citing the United Nations' Declaration on the Right to Development, the author says that “saving people is the highest form of human rights”– and that is exactly what China did with its harsh, police controlled total clampdown.
“Now that the outbreak has been almost controlled, the government has decided to gradually resume production and other economic activities,” the paper says, while the more liberal Caixin Global reports that cities in Hubei province are now relaxing traffic restrictions, and even cutting down on temperature checks.
Overseas help
Meanwhile, China has stepped up help to the new coronavirus hotspots, Iran, Italy and others. Iran’s Mehr News Agency reports that China sent 30 tons of medical aid to Tehran, the fourth such shipment, including 23 million face masks, 20 million three-layered masks, and three million high-quality N95 face masks.
Beijing also sent equipment and doctors to Italy, now the hardest hit country in the epidemic. According to Ansa press agency, the Chinese delivered over 2 million face masks and some 10,000 pulmonary ventilators. “Our doctors don't need anyone to teach them their job,” Italian Foreign Minister Luigi di Maio was quoted as saying, “but the Chinese doctors were the first to treat the virus and they can bring their experience."
Despite an ongoing and increasingly bitter war of words between Beijing and Washington, and the mutual expulsion of journalists, Chinese individuals like billionaire owner of retail giant AliBaba, Jack Ma, threw the full weight of his foundation into the fight against the coronavirus – and that included shipments of test kits. “All the best to our friends in America,” he tweeted.

Brussels guarantees efforts to overcome coronavirus outbreak "as soon as possible". The European Commission guaranteed this Friday "do everything it can" to overcome the outbreak of the new coronavirus "as soon as possible", stressing that this is a "fundamental moment" for the countries of the European Union (EU) to adopt measures. "I want to take this opportunity to send my condolences to all who have been affected by this recent outbreak and to ensure that we are doing everything possible, as the European Commission and with Member States, to overcome it as quickly as possible. ", declared the European Health Commissioner, Stella Kyriakides. Speaking to the press at the entrance to a meeting of EU health ministers on the outbreak in Brussels, the official noted that "Today's Council is held at a pivotal moment in terms of efforts to meet the challenge of Covid-19" . "We are going to look at the preparation of Member States, their needs, but also the need to be in solidarity at this time," concluded Stella Kyriakides. EU health ministers have a new extraordinary meeting in Brussels today, the second in less than a month, to discuss coordinated measures to respond to the Covid-19 outbreak, which continues to spread across Europe. This meeting, in which Portugal will be represented by the Minister of Health, Marta Temido, takes place about three weeks after the first extraordinary Health Council, held on February 13th in Brussels, to discuss the strengthening of coordination between Member States in efforts to contain the spread of the new coronavirus, which has intensified in the meantime, leading to the EU risk assessment being raised to "moderate to high". The Covid-19 outbreak, which can cause respiratory infections such as pneumonia, has caused more than 3,450 deaths and infected more than 97,000 people in at least 86 countries, including nine in Portugal. Until midnight on Friday (16:00 hours on Thursday in Lisbon), mainland China, which excludes Macau and Hong Kong, had a total of 3,042 deaths and 80,552 cases of infection, more than 80 % of global pool worldwide, despite recent outbreaks in Italy, Iran, South Korea and Japan. China reported that more than 53,700 people have been discharged in the country since the outbreak of the outbreak. In addition to 3,042 deaths in Mainland China, there are reports of fatalities in Iran, Italy, South Korea, Japan, France, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Australia, Thailand, United States, Philippines, Spain, United Kingdom and Iraq.

Coronavirus curfew means tough times for Hong Kong domestic workers. Of the over 300,000 workers living in Hong Kong, the majority come from the Philippines, according to government statistics.
Wilma Francisco Tolentino is one of them.
"I arrived here last September 13, 2016. Before things were normal, I could take a day off and go anywhere. But now, there are so many changes," she told RFI.
Tolentino, who was hired by French babysitting company HelperChoice to take care of three children, has been practically confined indoors since the coronavirus or Covid-19 broke out in the Chinese city of Wuhan.
"I don't take the kids out, we always stay at home. I only go out if I really need to go to the market, but mostly it's my employer who goes out," she comments.
Health officials in Hong Kong on Friday confirmed three additional coronavirus cases, bringing the city-wide total to 56.
Globally, more than 1,300 people are now known to have died from the pneumonia-like virus.
No rest
In the Hong Kong capital, already the setting for months of simmering protests, a new emotion runs in the air: fear.
"Now, we really need to be careful and take extra precautions and we must really practice good hygiene," explains Tolentino, who regularly sanitizes her employer's home, especially the bathroom and toilet.
"We need to wear masks because we don’t know where and when the virus will be transmitted to us. It’s a matter of life and death, because the coronavirus is still not curable. Since, I’m a single parent with a daughter, I’m really scared about my life.”
Adding to the strain are curfew restrictions. Last week, the Hong Kong Labour Department issued a statement calling for foreign domestic workers to "stay home on their rest day" to minimise the spread of Covid-19.
"It's hard," says Tolentino, already feeling the toll of being confined.
Free of care
"Before, I had my boarding house and everytime on my day off I could go there to rest and at least sleep for 2-3 hours."
Not anymore. After a full week of babysitting, she lacks privacy to switch off.
"It’s really hard taking care of three kids. The kids here, they are a little bit naughty, and I really need to rest, but now I just sit down, I cannot rest."
As scientists race to find a vaccine, Tolentino is praying for things to return to normal.
Normal for her means going out "without fear in our hearts of catching the virus."
"Life only comes once." She wants it to be carefree.
